result.markdown:
--- title: "Shiny App - Mass Shootings in the USA" description: "EDA with Shiny app on mass shootings between August 20th, 1982 and December 6th, 2023." date: "2023-03-01" categories: - r - shiny - eda - data cleaning - data wrangling image: images/preview.png --- ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple"} This post will be regularly updated with each new case. Last update on January 5, 2024. :::
## Introduction Mass shootings have been a topic of intense discussion in the United States. A public "database" of mass shootings since 1982 has been made available by the [Mother Jones](https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/12/mass-shootings-mother-jones-full-data/), a non-profit organization. This "database" is stored in a Google spreadsheet. You can access it [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1b9o6uDO18sLxBqPwl_Gh9bnhW-ev_dABH83M5Vb5L8o/edit#gid=0) and download as a CSV file. There are many definitions of mass shooting. Here is what [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mass-shooting) has to say: > ***Mass shooting**, also called **active shooter incident**, as defined by the U.S. [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Federal-Bureau-of-Investigation) (FBI), an event in which one or more individuals are "**actively engaged in killing or attempting to kill people in a populated area.** Implicit in this definition is the shooter's use of a firearm." The FBI has not set a minimum number of casualties to qualify an event as a mass shooting, but U.S. statute (the Investigative Assistance for Violent Crimes Act of 2012) defines a "mass killing" as **"3 or more killings in a single incident".*** ## Data overview ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(tidygeocoder) library(plotly) theme_set(theme_classic()) mass_shootings <- read_csv("data/mass_shootings_usa_1982-2023.csv") mass_shootings %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 149 Columns: 24 $ case "UNLV shooting", "Maine bowling alley‚Ä¶ $ location...2 "Las Vegas, Nevada", "Lewiston, Maine‚Ä¶ $ date "12/6/23", "10/25/23", "8/26/23", "8/‚Ä¶ $ summary "Anthony Polito, 67, a former univers‚Ä¶ $ fatalities 3, 18, 3, 3, 5, 3, 8, 5, 6, 3, 7, 11,‚Ä¶ $ injured 1, 13, 0, 6, 2, 6, 7, 8, 6, 5, 1, 10,‚Ä¶ $ total_victims 4, 31, 3, 9, 7, 9, 15, 13, 12, 8, 8, ‚Ä¶ $ location...8 "School", "Other", "workplace", "Othe‚Ä¶ $ age_of_shooter "67", "40", "21", "59", "40", "18", "‚Ä¶ $ prior_signs_mental_health_issues "-", "yes", "yes", "-", "yes", "yes",‚Ä¶ $ mental_health_details "-", "Card reportedly spoke of \"hear‚Ä¶ $ weapons_obtained_legally "-", "-", "yes", "-", "yes", "yes", "‚Ä¶ $ where_obtained "-", "Yes", "local gun stores", "-", ‚Ä¶ $ weapon_type "semiautomatic handgun", "semiautomat‚Ä¶ $ weapon_details "-", "AR-15-style rifle (Rugar SFAR)"‚Ä¶ $ race "White", "White", "White", "White", "‚Ä¶ $ gender "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M‚Ä¶ $ sources "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news‚Ä¶ $ mental_health_sources "-", "https://www.nytimes.com/article‚Ä¶ $ sources_additional_age "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-‚Ä¶ $ latitude "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-‚Ä¶ $ longitude "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-‚Ä¶ $ type "mass", "Spree", "mass", "mass", "mas‚Ä¶ $ year 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: We have 149 cases, described with 24 variables. At first glance, this dataset clearly needs extensive cleaning. ## Data cleaning ### üßπ Step 1. Initial cleaning The first cleaning step includes: - selecting columns of interest, - replacing the character value `"-"` with `NA` in all columns with character data type, - converting `date` column from character to date data type, - renaming location columns, - converting character data type to numeric for specific columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln <- mass_shootings %>% select(1:6, 8:10, 12, 16, 17, 21:24) %>% mutate(across(where(is.character), ~na_if(., "-"))) %>% mutate(date = lubridate::mdy(date)) %>% rename(location = location...2, location_2 = location...8) %>% mutate_at(c("injured", "age_of_shooter", "latitude", "longitude"), as.numeric) mass_shootings_cln %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 149 Columns: 16 $ case "UNLV shooting", "Maine bowling alley‚Ä¶ $ location "Las Vegas, Nevada", "Lewiston, Maine‚Ä¶ $ date 2023-12-06, 2023-10-25, 2023-08-26, ‚Ä¶ $ summary "Anthony Polito, 67, a former univers‚Ä¶ $ fatalities 3, 18, 3, 3, 5, 3, 8, 5, 6, 3, 7, 11,‚Ä¶ $ injured 1, 13, 0, 6, 2, 6, 7, 8, 6, 5, 1, 10,‚Ä¶ $ location_2 "School", "Other", "workplace", "Othe‚Ä¶ $ age_of_shooter 67, 40, 21, 59, 40, 18, 33, 25, 28, 4‚Ä¶ $ prior_signs_mental_health_issues NA, "yes", "yes", NA, "yes", "yes", "‚Ä¶ $ weapons_obtained_legally NA, NA, "yes", NA, "yes", "yes", "yes‚Ä¶ $ race "White", "White", "White", "White", "‚Ä¶ $ gender "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M", "M‚Ä¶ $ latitude NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N‚Ä¶ $ longitude NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N‚Ä¶ $ type "mass", "Spree", "mass", "mass", "mas‚Ä¶ $ year 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2023, 2‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: üîé Are there any duplicates? No. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sum(duplicated(mass_shootings)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: üîé Number of missing values, `NA`, per column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>% # transposing for better visibility pivot_longer(cols = everything(), names_to = "column", values_to = "n_missing") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 16 √ó 2 column n_missing 1 case 0 2 location 0 3 date 0 4 summary 0 5 fatalities 0 6 injured 0 7 location_2 0 8 age_of_shooter 2 9 prior_signs_mental_health_issues 30 10 weapons_obtained_legally 19 11 race 12 12 gender 0 13 latitude 23 14 longitude 23 15 type 0 16 year 0 ``` ::: ::: 23 of the most recent cases don't have location coordinates at all. We'll address this in the final cleanup step. ### üßπ Step 2. Fixing unique values of categorical variables üîé Let's take a look at the unique values of the `gender` column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln %>% count(gender, sort = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 2 gender n 1 "M" 73 2 "Male" 70 3 "Female" 2 4 "Male & Female" 2 5 "F" 1 6 "F (\"identifies as transgender\" and \"Audrey Hale is a biological wom‚Ä¶ 1 ``` ::: ::: Almost all categorical variables need unique values correction. To make a long story short, I'll correct them all in one step using `case_when` function, and we'll look at them later during the analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln <- mass_shootings_cln %>% mutate(gender = case_when(gender == "F" ~ "Female", gender == "M" ~ "Male", gender == "(see summary)" ~ "Male", gender %>% str_detect("transgender")~"Female (transgender)", TRUE ~ gender), race = case_when(race == "white" ~ "White", race == "black" ~ "Black", race == "unclear" ~ "Unclear", TRUE ~ race), location_2 = case_when(location_2 %in% c("workplace", "\nWorkplace") ~ "Workplace", location_2 == "Other\n" ~ "Other", location_2 == "religious" ~ "Religious", TRUE ~ location_2), prior_signs_mental_health_issues = case_when(prior_signs_mental_health_issues == "yes" ~ "Yes", prior_signs_mental_health_issues == "TBD" ~ "To be determined", TRUE ~ prior_signs_mental_health_issues), weapons_obtained_legally = case_when(weapons_obtained_legally %in% c("yes", "\nYes") ~ "Yes", weapons_obtained_legally == "TBD" ~ "To be determined", weapons_obtained_legally %>% str_detect("Kelley") ~ "Unknown", weapons_obtained_legally %>% str_detect("some") ~ "Partially", TRUE ~ weapons_obtained_legally), type = case_when(type == "mass" ~ "Mass", TRUE ~ type)) ``` ::: ### üßπ Step 3. Geocoding locations with missing coordinates There are 23 cases with missing location coordinates. In this step we'll convert locations to coordinates with geocoding. and use them later to create a `leaflet` map for a `shiny app`. The `tidygeocoder` package provides geocoding services. It's designed to work easily with the `tidyverse.` It also provides access to several different geocoding services, including [LocationIQ](https://locationiq.com/) which I'm going to use here. LocationIQ is a freemium service that provides a free tier, which doesn't require you to give them your billing details. When you sign up to LocationIQ, they'll take you to the Manage Your API Access Tokens page, which is where we obtain our API token. Next, you need to provide the `tidygeocoder` package with your API key. You can also use the [Nominatim ("osm")](https://nominatim.org/) geocoding service (OpenStreetMap) which can be specified with the method argument (`method = "osm"`). I found LocationIQ to be faster. The first step is to select only locations with missing coordinates and geocode them. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} geocoded_locations <- mass_shootings_cln %>% filter(is.na(latitude) | is.na(longitude)) %>% select(location) %>% geocode(location, method = "iq") geocoded_locations %>% mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~ num(., digits = 6))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 23 √ó 3 location lat long 1 Las Vegas, Nevada 36.167256 -115.148516 2 Lewiston, Maine 44.095108 -70.215545 3 Jacksonville, Florida 30.332184 -81.655651 4 Trabuco Canyon, California 33.662623 -117.589380 5 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 39.952724 -75.163526 6 Farmington, New Mexico 36.729115 -108.205445 7 Allen, Texas 33.103174 -96.670550 8 Louisville, Kentucky 38.254238 -85.759407 9 Nashville, Tennessee 36.162277 -86.774298 10 East Lansing, Michigan 42.732031 -84.472168 # ‚Ñπ 13 more rows ``` ::: ::: The next step is to join mass shootings table with geocoded locations and replace missing latitudes and longitudes with geocoded. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln <- mass_shootings_cln %>% left_join(geocoded_locations, by = "location") %>% mutate(latitude = ifelse(is.na(latitude), lat, latitude), longitude = ifelse(is.na(longitude), long, longitude)) ``` ::: üîé Checking for null values. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sum(is.na(mass_shootings_cln$latitude)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sum(is.na(mass_shootings_cln$longitude)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: OK, this looks fine. ## Exploratory data analysis (EDA) ### ‚ùï Writing a function To count unique values for all categorical variables separately, I'll write a function, `count_unique`, to avoid copying and pasting a block of code several times. Here we have a special case where we have to pass a dataframe column name (variable) to a function argument. The solution is to embrace the argument by surrounding it in doubled braces, like `group_by({{ var }})`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique <- function(data, var) { data %>% group_by({{ var }}) %>% summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>% mutate(percent = scales::percent(count/sum(count), accuracy = 0.1)) %>% arrange(desc(count)) } ``` ::: ### üìÑ Breakdown by categorical variables #### Gender ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, gender) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 3 gender count percent 1 Male 143 96.0% 2 Female 3 2.0% 3 Male & Female 2 1.3% 4 Female (transgender) 1 0.7% ``` ::: ::: #### Race ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, race) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 8 √ó 3 race count percent 1 White 80 53.7% 2 Black 26 17.4% 3 Latino 12 8.1% 4 12 8.1% 5 Asian 10 6.7% 6 Other 5 3.4% 7 Native American 3 2.0% 8 Unclear 1 0.7% ``` ::: ::: #### Specific location ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, location_2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 location_2 count percent 1 Other 58 38.9% 2 Workplace 53 35.6% 3 School 23 15.4% 4 Religious 8 5.4% 5 Military 6 4.0% 6 Airport 1 0.7% ``` ::: ::: #### Prior signs of mental health issues ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, prior_signs_mental_health_issues) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 prior_signs_mental_health_issues count percent 1 Yes 72 48.3% 2 30 20.1% 3 Unclear 24 16.1% 4 No 17 11.4% 5 To be determined 5 3.4% 6 Unknown 1 0.7% ``` ::: ::: #### Weapons obtained legally ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, weapons_obtained_legally) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 weapons_obtained_legally count percent 1 Yes 99 66.4% 2 19 12.8% 3 No 16 10.7% 4 To be determined 7 4.7% 5 Unknown 7 4.7% 6 Partially 1 0.7% ``` ::: ::: #### Type ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_unique(mass_shootings_cln, type) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 3 type count percent 1 Mass 127 85.2% 2 Spree 22 14.8% ``` ::: ::: Note: Spree shootings have three or more victims in a short time in multiple locations. ### üìä Age of shooter distribution ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code for creating the age_group column"} # create "age group" column mass_shootings_cln <- mass_shootings_cln %>% mutate(age_group = case_when( age_of_shooter >= 10 & age_of_shooter <= 14 ~ "10-14", age_of_shooter <= 19 ~ "15-19", age_of_shooter <= 24 ~ "20-24", age_of_shooter <= 29 ~ "25-29", age_of_shooter <= 34 ~ "30-34", age_of_shooter <= 39 ~ "35-39", age_of_shooter <= 44 ~ "40-44", age_of_shooter <= 49 ~ "45-49", age_of_shooter <= 54 ~ "50-54", age_of_shooter <= 59 ~ "55-59", age_of_shooter <= 64 ~ "60-64", age_of_shooter <= 69 ~ "65-69", age_of_shooter <= 74 ~ "70-74")) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p1 <- mass_shootings_cln %>% filter(!is.na(age_group)) %>% group_by(age_group) %>% summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>% mutate(percent = scales::percent(count/sum(count), accuracy = 0.1)) %>% mutate(label_text = str_glue("Age group: {age_group} Count: {count} Percent: {percent}")) %>% ggplot(aes(x = age_group, y = count, text = label_text)) + geom_col(width = 0.7, fill = "indianred") + labs(title = "Age Distribution", x = "age group") ggplotly(p1, tooltip = "text") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
- The vast majority of shooters were between 15 and 50 years old. - The age distribution is bimodal, with one mode around 23 years of age and a second mode around 41 years of age. - Most shooters were in the 20-24 age group (18.4 %), followed by 40-44 (17 %) and 25-29 (15.6 %). üîé Who was the youngest shooter? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mass_shootings_cln %>% slice_min(age_of_shooter, n = 1) %>% select(case, date, summary, fatalities) %>% knitr::kable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} |case |date |summary | fatalities| |:-------------------------------|:----------|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------:| |Westside Middle School killings |1998-03-24 |Mitchell Scott Johnson, 13, and Andrew Douglas Golden, 11, two juveniles, ambushed students and teachers as they left the school; they were apprehended by police at the scene. | 5| ::: ::: ### üìä Number of cases per year ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p2 <- mass_shootings_cln %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% ggplot(aes(year, count)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") + geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "indianred", size = 0.7) + labs(title = "Number of Cases per Year") ggplotly(p2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
- We can see an increase in mass shootings in the last 12 years. - 2020 has a smaller number of cases probably due to Covid restrictions. ### üìä Fatalities-Injured relationship ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p3 <- mass_shootings_cln %>% ggplot(aes(x = fatalities, y = injured)) + geom_jitter() + scale_y_sqrt() + labs(title = "Fatalities-Injured Relationship") ggplotly(p3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
Please note that the `Injured` values are square root scaled for better visibility, but you can see the actual values by hovering over the points. **Summary of fatalities** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(mass_shootings_cln$fatalities) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 3.000 4.000 6.000 7.711 8.000 58.000 ``` ::: ::: **Summary of injured people** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(mass_shootings_cln$injured) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 0.00 1.00 3.00 10.93 10.00 546.00 ``` ::: ::: ### üìä Total fatalities by state #### üõ†Ô∏è Data manipulation ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # create us states with abbreviations tibble states_with_abbr <- tibble(state = state.name, abbr = state.abb) %>% bind_rows(tibble(state = "District of Columbia", abbr = "DC")) # data manipulation by_state <- mass_shootings_cln %>% # recode D.d. to District of Columbia mutate(location = ifelse(location == "Washington, D.C.", "Washington, District of Columbia", location)) %>% # separate location into city and state separate(location, c("city", "state"), sep = ", ") %>% # group and summarize group_by(state) %>% summarise(total_cases = n(), total_fatalities = sum(fatalities), .groups = "drop") %>% # add us states abbreviations left_join(states_with_abbr, by = "state") %>% # rearrange columns select(state, abbr, everything()) ``` ::: #### üìà Top ten states regarding number of cases and fatalities ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} by_state %>% arrange(-total_cases, -total_fatalities) %>% head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 √ó 4 state abbr total_cases total_fatalities 1 California CA 26 178 2 Texas TX 13 159 3 Florida FL 13 129 4 Colorado CO 8 53 5 Washington WA 7 37 6 Pennsylvania PA 6 32 7 New York NY 5 40 8 Wisconsin WI 5 28 9 Illinois IL 5 25 10 Virginia VA 4 53 ``` ::: ::: #### üìä Total fatalities by state visualization ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} by_state %>% plot_geo(locationmode = 'USA-states') %>% add_trace(z = ~total_fatalities, locations = ~abbr, color = ~total_fatalities, colors = ~"Reds") %>% layout( geo = list( scope = "usa", projection = list(type = "albers usa"), lakecolor = toRGB("white") ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Shiny app The app you can see below is embedded in this `quarto` document since my website is static. It was originally published on [shinyapps.io](https://sandra-jurela.shinyapps.io/shiny-mass-shootings-usa/), where you can also interact with it. **Note:** If you don't see the application, I've run out of my 25 active hours (when my applications are not idle). Sorry, this is a free account, and my app will not be available again until the following month cycle. Hope you get lucky! üòä üì¢ By clicking on each circle, you can read a summary of the mass shooting case.
::: column-screen ::: Thanks for reading!
